Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Thermal Insulation from Paper Mill Wastes
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project is the potential to produce superior, cost effective thermal insulation using paper mill short fiber residuals (SFR) alone or in addition to pulp from increasingly available old cardboard cartons (OCC). This will be an important step in eliminating thousands of tons of paper mill wastes being disposed of in landfills each day. Cellulose insulation is in demand by builders and retrofitters because of its superior performance, safety, and environmental benefits. This project could expand knowledge on the use of forest products and directed towards energy efficiency and sustainability enhancements in insulation applications.

The technical objectives of this Phase I research project are to research and prove the feasibility of combining SFR, a waste by-product from linerboard mills now being disposed of in landfills, with pulp from increasingly abundant OCC to produce a superior cellulose insulation that can be cost-effectively employed to insulate buildings and enhance environmental sustainaiblity. The manufacturing process embeds fire-retardant chemicals directly into the insulation's cellulose fibers thus eliminating loose powder-waste and respiratory problems from chemical-containing airborne dust. The research project will run controlled sets of experiments utilizing various blends of SFR and OCC in order to quantify relationships between various process factors and desired product characteristics for applications in traditional wooden structures as well as for spray-applications in increasingly necessary metal buildings. A successful outcome from this project will facilitate commercialization of a product that out-performs competing insulation products and that can be sustainably produced at dramatically lower costs - transforming the entire insulation industry by turning industrial wastes into superior thermal insulation.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
The primary objective of this NSF Phase I SBIR research was to demonstrate the technical feasibility of producing high-performance cellulose building insulation from paper mill residuals using an innovative, patented process developed by UltraCell Insulation, LLC (UltraCell).  Conventional cellulose insulation is made primarily from old newsprint, and supplies have declined dramatically in recent years as a result of a widespread shift to digital media, threatening the long-term viability of the industry.  UltraCell’s efforts to utilize new feedstock blends, in particular those that would be destined for landfills, has the potential to transform the insulation industry, to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, and to convert landfill-bound fiber residuals into a valuable building product.

The Phase I research involved experimental lab work conducted at both the University of Maine Process Development Center (PDC) and UltraCell’s newly established laboratory in Tewksbury, MA. The project team ran a series of designed experiments to determine the impact of feedstock selection and blends on resulting product characteristics. Our goal was not only to identify a single blend that met our requirements for full-scale production, but also to characterize the impacts various combinations of materials and process parameters have on final product quality.

We conducted experiments with 10 different product prototypes, while carefully controlling key process parameters to ensure the results would be accurate and repeatable. All prototypes were tested against a series of regulatory and customer-driven product performance standards. Our findings were very positive and informative.  We have identified a fiber blend that meets basic regulatory requirements, and a blend that exceeds the industry standard for R-value.  More importantly, we have gained an understanding of the complex interaction of fibers and processing methods that will enable us to focus on developing products that outperform competing insulation products and can be sustainably produced at dramatically lower cost during Phase II. 

 


Last Modified: 08/29/2016
Modified by: Daniel H Thompson
